prompt:
[INST] Character Info: Mr. Harris: A bureaucratic and detached official, speaking in a measured and impersonal tone, more concerned with rules than people.
Ronny Heaslop: Rigid and self-important, speaking in clipped, authoritative tones, deeply loyal to British rule and dismissive of local perspectives.
Mrs. Moore: Gentle and introspective, speaking with empathy and curiosity, often questioning the rigidity of colonial attitudes.
Adela Quested: Intelligent but uncertain, speaking hesitantly, torn between her ideals and the realities of colonial India.
Miss Derek: Flippant and carefree, speaking in a breezy, irreverent tone, more interested in adventure than propriety.


Dialogue History: Adela Quested: We must have a thorough talk, Ronny, I'm afraid.
Ronny Heaslop: My temper's rotten, I must apologize, I didn't mean to order you and mother about, but of course the way those Bengalis let you down this morning annoyed me, and I don't want that sort of thing to keep happening.
Adela Quested: It's nothing to do with them that I . . .
Ronny Heaslop: No, but Aziz would make some similar muddle over the caves. He meant nothing by the invitation, I could tell by his voice; it's just their way of being pleasant.
Adela Quested: It's something very different, nothing to do with caves, that I wanted to talk over with you.
Adela Quested: I've finally decided we are not going to be married, my dear boy.
Ronny Heaslop: You never said we should marry, my dear girl; you never bound either yourself or me   don't let this upset you.
Adela Quested: But let us discuss things; it's all so frightfully important, we mustn't make false steps. I want next to hear your point of view about me   it might help us both.
Ronny Heaslop: I don't much believe in this discussing   besides, I'm so dead with all this extra work Mohurram's bringing, if you'll excuse me.
Adela Quested: I only want everything to be absolutely clear between us, and to answer any questions you care to put to me on my conduct.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Ronny Heaslop: But I haven't got any questions. You've acted within your rights, you were quite right to come out and have a look at me doing my work, it was an excellent plan, and anyhow it's no use talking further   we should only get up steam.

prompt:
[INST] Character Info: Ronny Heaslop: Rigid and self-important, speaking in clipped, authoritative tones, deeply loyal to British rule and dismissive of local perspectives.
Mrs. Mcbryde: Cold and detached, mirroring her husband's superiority complex, speaking with passive disdain for Indian culture.
Mr. Mcbryde: A condescending but methodical policeman, convinced of his own intellectual superiority, speaking in a patronizing manner.
Mrs. Moore: Gentle and introspective, speaking with empathy and curiosity, often questioning the rigidity of colonial attitudes.
Adela Quested: Intelligent but uncertain, speaking hesitantly, torn between her ideals and the realities of colonial India.


Dialogue History: Ronny Heaslop: She never mentioned that name once.
Adela Quested: But, Ronny, I heard her.
Ronny Heaslop: Pure illusion. You can't be quite well, can you, to make up a thing like that.
Adela Quested: I suppose I can't. How amazing of me!
Ronny Heaslop: I was listening to all she said, as far as it could be listened to; she gets very incoherent.
Adela Quested: When her voice dropped she said it   towards the end, when she talked about love   love   I couldn't follow, but just then she said:    Doctor Aziz never did it.'
Ronny Heaslop: Those words?
Adela Quested: The idea more than the words.
Ronny Heaslop: Never, never, my dear girl. Complete illusion. His name was not mentioned by anyone. Look here   you are confusing this with Fielding's letter.
Adela Quested: That's it, that's it, I knew I'd heard his name somewhere. I am so grateful to you for clearing this up   it's the sort of mistake that worries me, and proves I'm neurotic.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Ronny Heaslop: So you won't go saying he's innocent again, will you? for every servant I've got is a spy.

prompt:
[INST] Character Info: Hamidullah: Warm and intelligent, with a deep sense of justice, speaking with a mix of humor and frustration at colonial rule.
Mr. Turton: Authoritative and patronizing, speaking with the certainty of colonial superiority, preferring control over understanding.
Dr. Aziz: Warm and idealistic, speaking with enthusiasm and emotion, easily hurt by slights but eager for friendship.
Hassan: A dutiful and hardworking man, speaking respectfully, rarely offering personal opinions unless pressed.
Cyril Fielding: Rational and fair-minded, speaking with a dry wit and intellectual curiosity, skeptical of both colonial and nationalist extremes.


Dialogue History: Dr. Aziz: That pure-minded fellow. However, he will blame the Indian climate. Everything is our fault really. Now, have I not discovered an important piece of news for you, Cyril?
Cyril Fielding: Not very, Listen to mine. At the conference, it was settled. . . .
Dr. Aziz: This evening will do for schoolmastery. I should go straight to the Minto now, the cholera looks bad. We begin to have local cases as well as imported. In fact, the whole of life is somewhat sad. The new Civil Surgeon is the same as the last, but does not yet dare to be. That is all any administrative change amounts to. All my suffering has won nothing for us. But look here, Cyril, while I remember it. There's gossip about you as well as McBryde. They say that you and Miss Quested became also rather too intimate friends. To speak perfectly frankly, they say you and she have been guilty of impropriety.
Cyril Fielding: They would say that.
Dr. Aziz: It's all over the town, and may injure your reputation. You know, everyone is by no means your supporter. I have tried all I could to silence such a story.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Cyril Fielding: Don't bother. Miss Quested has cleared out at last.

prompt:
[INST] Character Info: Ronny Heaslop: Rigid and self-important, speaking in clipped, authoritative tones, deeply loyal to British rule and dismissive of local perspectives.
Mrs. Mcbryde: Cold and detached, mirroring her husband's superiority complex, speaking with passive disdain for Indian culture.
Mr. Mcbryde: A condescending but methodical policeman, convinced of his own intellectual superiority, speaking in a patronizing manner.
Mrs. Moore: Gentle and introspective, speaking with empathy and curiosity, often questioning the rigidity of colonial attitudes.
Adela Quested: Intelligent but uncertain, speaking hesitantly, torn between her ideals and the realities of colonial India.


Dialogue History: Adela Quested: I think you're rather unkind not to say.
Mrs. Moore: Say, say, say,
Mrs. Moore: As if anything can be said! I have spent my life in saying or in listening to sayings; I have listened too much. It is time I was left in peace. Not to die, No doubt you expect me to die, but when I have seen you and Ronny married, and seen the other two and whether they want to be married   I'll retire then into a cave of my own. Somewhere where no young people will come asking questions and expecting answers. Some shelf.
Ronny Heaslop: Quite so, but meantime a trial is coming on, and the notion of most of us is that we'd better pull together and help one another through, instead of being disagreeable. Are you going to talk like that in the witness-box?
Mrs. Moore: Why should I be in the witness-box?
Ronny Heaslop: To confirm certain points in our evidence.
Mrs. Moore: I have nothing to do with your ludicrous law courts, I will not be dragged in at all.
Adela Quested: I won't have her dragged in, either; I won't have any more trouble on my account, Her evidence is not the least essential.
Ronny Heaslop: I thought she would want to give it. No one blames you, mother, but the fact remains that you dropped off at the first cave, and encouraged Adela to go on with him alone, whereas if you'd been well enough to keep on too nothing would have happened. He planned it, I know. Still, you fell into his trap just like Fielding and Antony before you. . . . Forgive me for speaking so plainly, but you've no right to take up this high and mighty attitude about law courts. If you're ill, that's different; but you say you're all right and you seem so, in which case I thought you'ld want to take your part, I did really.
Adela Quested: I'll not have you worry her whether she's well or ill,

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Mrs. Moore: I shall attend your marriage, but not your trial, Then I shall go to England.

Dialogue History: Mr. Mcbryde: I didn't catch that answer.
Mr. Mcbryde: You are on that landing, or whatever we term it, and you have entered a cave. I suggest to you that the prisoner followed you.
Mr. Mcbryde: What do you mean, please?
Adela Quested: No,
Mr. Mcbryde: What is that, what are you saying? Speak up, please.
Adela Quested: I'm afraid I have made a mistake.
Mr. Mcbryde: What nature of mistake?
Adela Quested: Dr. Aziz never followed me into the cave.
Mr. Mcbryde: Now, Miss Quested, let us go on. I will read you the words of the deposition which you signed two hours later in my bungalow.
Mr. Das: Excuse me, Mr. McBryde, you cannot go on. I am speaking to the witness myself. And the public will be silent. If it continues to talk, I have the court cleared. Miss Quested, address your remarks to me, who am the Magistrate in charge of the case, and realize their extreme gravity. Remember you speak on oath, Miss Quested.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]

Ralph: Sensitive and introspective, speaking with a quiet curiosity, open to new ideas but hesitant to voice strong opinions.

Dialogue History: Dr. Aziz: His Highness's Private Secretary, probably.
Cyril Fielding: Where is he, then?
Dr. Aziz: I don't know.
Cyril Fielding: Because not a soul's been near us since we arrived.
Dr. Aziz: Really.
Cyril Fielding: I wrote beforehand to the Durbar, and asked if a visit was convenient. I was told it was, and arranged my tour accordingly; but the Guest House servants appear to have no definite instructions, we can't get any eggs, also my wife wants to go out in the boat.
Dr. Aziz: There are two boats.
Cyril Fielding: Exactly, and no oars.
Dr. Aziz: Colonel Maggs broke the oars when here last.
Cyril Fielding: All four?

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Dr. Aziz: He is a most powerful man.

Dialogue History: Mrs. Moore: A ghost!
Ronny Heaslop: Yes, nothing criminal, but there's the native, and there's one of the reasons why we don't admit him to our clubs, and how a decent girl like Miss Derek can take service under natives puzzles me. . . . But I must get on with my work. Krishna!
Mrs. Moore: Will you play Patience with your future mother-in-law, dear Adela, or does it seem too tame?
Adela Quested: I should like to   I don't feel a bit excited   I'm just glad it's settled up at last, but I'm not conscious of vast changes. We are all three the same people still.
Mrs. Moore: That's much the best feeling to have.
Adela Quested: I suppose so,
Mrs. Moore: I feared at Mr. Fielding's that it might be settled the other way . . . black knave on a red queen. . . .
Adela Quested: You heard me tell Aziz and Godbole I wasn't stopping in their country. I didn't mean it, so why did I say it? I feel I haven't been   frank enough, attentive enough, or something. It's as if I got everything out of proportion. You have been so very good to me, and I meant to be good when I sailed, but somehow I haven't been. . . . Mrs. Moore, if one isn't absolutely honest, what is the use of existing?
Mrs. Moore: I wouldn't worry, It's partly the odd surroundings; you and I keep on attending to trifles instead of what's important; we are what the people here call    new.'
Adela Quested: You mean that my bothers are mixed up with India?

 [/INST]

Dialogue History: Cyril Fielding: Is there a short cut down to our carriage? We must give up our walk. The weather's pestilential.
Dr. Aziz: Yes. That way.
Cyril Fielding: Are you not coming down yourself?
Cyril Fielding: How goes it, Aziz?
Dr. Aziz: In my usual health.
Cyril Fielding: Are you making anything out of your life here?
Dr. Aziz: How much do you make out of yours?
Cyril Fielding: Who is in charge of the Guest House?
Dr. Aziz: His Highness's Private Secretary, probably.
Cyril Fielding: Where is he, then?

The Servant: Quiet and deferential, speaking only when addressed, trained to be invisible in British households.

Dialogue History: Hamidullah: Come and see my wife a little then,
Dr. Aziz: Once is enough.
Hamidullah: Yes, he has done his duty, Do not tease him so. He carries on his family, two boys and their sister.
Dr. Aziz: Aunt, they live most comfortably with my wife's mother, where she was living when she died. I can see them whenever I like. They are such very, very small children.
Hamidullah: And he sends them the whole of his salary and lives like a low-grade clerk, and tells no one the reason. What more do you require him to do?
Hamidullah Begum: What is to become of all our daughters if men refuse to marry? They will marry beneath them, or
Dr. Aziz: Perhaps . . . but later . . .
Hamidullah: You mustn't put off what you think right, That is why India is in such a plight, because we put off things.
Dr. Aziz: Old Callendar wants to see me at his bungalow, He might have the politeness to say why.
Hamidullah: Some case, I daresay.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Dr. Aziz: I daresay not, I daresay nothing. He has found out our dinner hour, that's all, and chooses to interrupt us every time, in order to show his power.

prompt:
[INST] Character Info: Hamidullah: Warm and intelligent, with a deep sense of justice, speaking with a mix of humor and frustration at colonial rule.
Dr. Aziz: Warm and idealistic, speaking with enthusiasm and emotion, easily hurt by slights but eager for friendship.
Cyril Fielding: Rational and fair-minded, speaking with a dry wit and intellectual curiosity, skeptical of both colonial and nationalist extremes.


Dialogue History: Cyril Fielding: They can't well move me down, whatever their feelings.
Dr. Aziz: In any case we spend our holidays together, and visit Kashmir, possibly Persia, for I shall have plenty of money. Paid to me on account of the injury sustained by my character, While with me you shall never spend a single pie. This is what I have always wished, and as the result of my misfortunes it has come.
Cyril Fielding: You have won a great victory . . .
Dr. Aziz: I know, my dear chap, I know; your voice need not become so solemn and anxious. I know what you are going to say next: Let, oh let Miss Quested off paying, so that the English may say,
Dr. Aziz: The approval of your compatriots no longer interests me, I have become anti-British, and ought to have done so sooner, it would have saved me numerous misfortunes.
Cyril Fielding: Including knowing me.
Dr. Aziz: I say, shall we go and pour water on to Mohammed Latif's face? He is so funny when this is done to him asleep.
Cyril Fielding: Yes, certainly you must let off Miss Quested easily. She must pay all your costs, that is only fair, but do not treat her like a conquered enemy.
Dr. Aziz: Is she wealthy? I depute you to find out.
Cyril Fielding: The sums mentioned at dinner when you all got so excited   they would ruin her, they are perfectly preposterous. Look here . . .

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Dr. Aziz: I am looking, though it gets a bit dark. I see Cyril Fielding to be a very nice chap indeed and my best friend, but in some ways a fool. You think that by letting Miss Quested off easily I shall make a better reputation for myself and Indians generally. No, no. It will be put down to weakness and the attempt to gain promotion officially. I have decided to have nothing more to do with British India, as a matter of fact. I shall seek service in some Moslem State, such as Hyderabad, Bhopal, where Englishmen cannot insult me any more. Don't counsel me otherwise.
